This recommendation is based on clinical trial findings that low-dose aspirin use is not associated with fetal harm and that it significantly reduces the risks for preeclampsia, preterm birth, and intrauterine growth restriction.

Other strategies to prevent preeclampsia include regular exercise, calcium supplementation, and labor induction.

Key learning point: To reduce the risk for preeclampsia in a twin gestation, prescribe low-dose aspirin.

D) INCORRECT:

A woman with a twin gestation who enters pregnancy at a normal weight typically gains 15 to 20 kg (i.e., substantially more than 11 kg).

E) INCORRECT:

Checking cervical length in a woman with risk factors for preterm birth is appropriate but has no place in reducing risk of preeclampsia.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old, gravida 3, para 2 woman at 37 weeks’ gestation presents with a one-week history of worsening edema in her hands and feet. She has no epigastric pain and no visual or neurologic disturbances. She has a history of chronic (preexisting) hypertension that is well controlled with labetalol.
Her current blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Her cervix is closed, 4 cm long, firm, and posterior; the fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis.
After urine dipstick analysis reveals 1+ protein, further laboratory testing is ordered. The results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hematocrit (%)
39
36–46


Platelet count (per mm3)
250,000
150,000–350,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.9
0.6–1.1


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
11
0–35


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
17
0–35


Urine protein-to-creatinine ratio (mg/mg)
0.4
<0.2


Fetal heart tracing reveals a baseline heart rate of 135 beats per minute with moderate variability, adequate accelerations, and no decelerations.
Tocometry reveals no contractions.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Magnesium sulfate for preventing eclampsia is recommended in the setting of severe features of preeclampsia, which this patient does not have.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s history of chronic hypertension, currently elevated blood pressure, and new-onset proteinuria indicate that she has developed superimposed preeclampsia. At 37 weeks’ gestation, her pregnancy is at term. The most appropriate next step is induction of labor, which has been shown to reduce the risks for adverse maternal outcomes and severe hypertension.

Chronic hypertension during pregnancy is defined as elevated blood pressure (systolic pressure ≥140 mm Hg or diastolic pressure ≥90 mm Hg on two occasions at least 4 hours apart) that existed before the pregnancy or that was diagnosed before 20 weeks’ gestation. Criteria for superimposed preeclampsia include preexisting hypertension during pregnancy and any of the following features:

• Proteinuria (≥300 mg in a 24-hour urine protein collection, a urine protein-to-creatinine ratio of ≥0.3 mg/mg, or a urine dipstick protein of 1+)
• Thrombocytopenia (platelet count <100,000/mm3)
• Elevated serum creatinine level (>1.1 mg/dL) or doubling of serum creatinine
• Elevated serum alanine or aspartate aminotransferase level to twice the normal concentration
• Pulmonary edema or neurologic or visual changes

Key learning point: For a pregnant woman at 37 weeks’ gestation who has chronic hypertension and new-onset proteinuria (a urine protein-to-creatinine ratio of ≥0.3 mg/mg), the most appropriate next step is induction of labor.

C) INCORRECT:

The decision to proceed to delivery does not necessitate cesarean section. Because this patient is stable, induction of labor should be initiated.

D) INCORRECT:

Antenatal glucocorticoid therapy with betamethasone or dexamethasone for fetal lung maturity should be administered to pregnant patients at risk for preterm delivery between 24 and 34 weeks’ gestation and can also be considered up to 37 weeks’ gestation. Given that this patient is at 37 weeks’ gestation, glucocorticoids for fetal lung maturity are not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Additional antihypertensive agents are warranted if the patient develops severe hypertension (systolic pressure ≥160 mm Hg or diastolic pressure ≥110 mm Hg).

questions.text:
A 24-year-old primigravida woman at 31 weeks' gestation is hospitalized with a blood pressure of 145/92 mm Hg and a urine dipstick showing 1+ proteinuria. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and she has no significant medical or surgical history.
During 24 hours of inpatient monitoring, she has no neurologic symptoms, visual changes, peripheral edema, or right upper quadrant pain.
Her systolic blood pressure ranges from 142 to 148 mm Hg, her diastolic blood pressure ranges from 90 to 96 mm Hg, and her heart rate ranges from 79 to 92 beats per minute. Her cervix is closed and 4 cm long; the fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis.
Her laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hematocrit (%)
37
28–40


Platelet count (per mm3)
350,000
146,000–429,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.7
0.4–0.9


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
10
2–25


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
14
4–32


24-hour protein excretion (mg)
325
0–254


Urine protein-to-creatinine ratio (mg/mg)
0.35
<0.20


A nonstress test is reactive with a baseline heart rate of 140 beats per minute with moderate variability, adequate accelerations, and no decelerations.
Tocometry reveals no contractions.
Ultrasound shows normal fetal growth parameters and a normal amniotic fluid index.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's care?

choices.text: Discharge for outpatient management, with clinic visits and fetal monitoring scheduled at short intervals
Start magnesium sulfate and continue to monitor in the hospital
Start methyldopa and continue to monitor in the hospital
Start labetalol, and discharge for outpatient management, with clinic visits and fetal monitoring scheduled at short intervals
Start magnesium sulfate, and plan for induction of labor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation and laboratory results are consistent with preeclampsia without severe features. Given that her blood pressure (BP) is persistently >140/90 mm Hg, antihypertensive therapy should be initiated. Once the patient’s BP elevation is mild, she can be discharged home with close outpatient monitoring.

B) INCORRECT:

Magnesium sulfate is not routinely used to prevent eclampsia in the setting of preeclampsia without severe features. This therapy would be considered if the patient had severe BP elevations or preeclampsia with severe features. Once the patient’s BP elevation is mild, she can be discharged home with close outpatient monitoring.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation and laboratory results are consistent with preeclampsia without severe features. Given that her blood pressure (BP) is persistently >140/90 mm Hg, antihypertensive therapy should be initiated. Once the patient’s BP elevation is mild, she can be discharged home with close outpatient monitoring.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation and laboratory results are consistent with preeclampsia without severe features. Given that her blood pressure (BP) is persistently >140/90 mm Hg, antihypertensive therapy should be initiated. This recommendation is based on data showing better outcomes with a treatment threshold of 140/90 mm Hg than with the previously recommended threshold of 160/110 mm Hg. Antihypertensive therapy in this setting typically consists of labetalol, nifedipine, or methyldopa.

Once the patient’s BP elevation is mild, she can be discharged home with close outpatient monitoring. Maternal BP and laboratory test results (complete blood count, creatinine measurement, and liver function tests) should be monitored weekly, and fetal well-being should be assessed twice weekly, with nonstress tests and amniotic fluid index measurements.

Preeclampsia with severe features would be an indication for continued hospitalization. Severe features include systolic BP ≥160 mm Hg and a diastolic BP ≥110 mm Hg on two occasions at least 4 hours apart, thrombocytopenia, impaired liver function, progressive renal insufficiency, pulmonary edema, or new onset of cerebral or visual disturbances.

Bed rest and low-salt diets have not been shown to improve pregnancy outcomes or delay the progression of disease in preeclampsia.

Key learning point: Patients who have preeclampsia without severe features can be managed expectantly in an outpatient setting.

E) INCORRECT:

Magnesium sulfate is not routinely used to prevent eclampsia in the setting of preeclampsia without severe features. This therapy would be considered if the patient had severe BP elevations or preeclampsia with severe features. Similarly, delivery is not indicated for preeclampsia without severe features.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old primigravida woman at 38 weeks' gestation presents with worsening epigastric abdominal pain. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and she has no significant medical history.
Her vital signs are normal other than a blood pressure of 165/105 mm Hg. Her cervix is 3 cm dilated, 90% effaced, at –1 station, soft, and in the anterior position.
Tocometry is performed (figure).
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range (third trimester)


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
9.0
9.5–15.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
85,000
146,000–429,000


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
80
4–32


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
1.3
0.1–1.1


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.3
0.4–0.9


Urine protein
3+
0


A peripheral blood smear is pending.
One hour after presentation, the patient is observed to have a 30-second tonic-clonic seizure. A nonstress test is reactive, showing the heart rate to be in the 130s with moderate variability and no accelerations or decelerations.
What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Infuse magnesium sulfate, and perform a caesarean delivery under spinal anesthesia
Perform an immediate cesarean delivery under general anesthesia
Transfuse platelets, place an epidural, and perform a caesarean delivery
Infuse magnesium sulfate, and initiate oxytocin augmentation of labor
Infuse phenytoin, order a platelet transfusion, and begin misoprostol induction of labor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The only curative treatment for severe preeclampsia or eclamptic seizure is expeditious delivery. However, this does not preclude attempting a vaginal delivery if the patient and fetus are hemodynamically stable, as they are in this case. A cesarean section is not required in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

A cesarean section is not required in this case, and induction of general anesthesia without initial administration of magnesium sulfate could result in another seizure.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's platelet count is low, it is high enough (>80,000) to safely receive epidural or spinal anesthesia. A platelet transfusion is not necessary. The only curative treatment for severe preeclampsia or eclamptic seizure is expeditious delivery. However, this does not preclude attempting a vaginal delivery if the patient and fetus are hemodynamically stable, as they are in this case. A cesarean section is not required in this case.

D) CORRECT:

This woman's laboratory findings are consistent with a severe form of preeclampsia known as the HELLP syndrome (hemolysis, elevated liver-enzyme levels, and low platelet count), and she has just suffered an eclamptic seizure. HELLP is diagnosed on the basis of a platelet count ≤100,000 cells per mm3, a total bilirubin level ≥1.2 mg/dL, an aspartate aminotransferase level ≥70 U/liter, and findings of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia on peripheral blood smear.

The only curative treatment for severe preeclampsia or eclamptic seizure is expeditious delivery. However, this does not preclude attempting a vaginal delivery if the patient and fetus are hemodynamically stable, as they are in this case.

All patients with severe preeclampsia and eclampsia should receive parenteral magnesium sulfate during labor and 24 hours postpartum to prevent seizures. Phenytoin is not as effective as magnesium sulfate for this purpose.

Although this patient's platelet count is low, it is high enough (>80,000) to safely receive epidural or spinal anesthesia. A platelet transfusion is not necessary.

Prostaglandins, such as misoprostol, can be used to ripen the cervix, but this patient's cervix is already favorable, and further cervical ripening before induction of labor is not necessary.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a woman presenting at term with eclampsia is magnesium sulfate and expeditious delivery of the fetus.

E) INCORRECT:

All patients with severe preeclampsia and eclampsia should receive parenteral magnesium sulfate during labor and 24 hours postpartum to prevent seizures. Phenytoin is not as effective as magnesium sulfate for this purpose. Although this patient's platelet count is low, it is high enough (>80,000) to safely receive epidural or spinal anesthesia. A platelet transfusion is not necessary. Prostaglandins, such as misoprostol, can be used to ripen the cervix, but this patient's cervix is already favorable, and further cervical ripening before induction of labor is not necessary.

questions.text: Six hours after giving birth to a healthy 3100 g (6 lb 13 oz) girl, a 40-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1 suddenly has a tonic-clonic seizure for 2 minutes while on the ward. She had been complaining of headache, blurry vision, and abdominal pain for an hour before the incident. Her pregnancy was complicated by gestational hypertension and iron deficiency anemia. Her medications until birth included labetalol, iron supplements, and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 152/100 mm Hg. The cranial nerves are intact. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ with a shortened relaxation phase. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium gluconate is indicated for the management of magnesium toxicity. As this patient has not yet received magnesium sulfate, there is no reason to administer calcium gluconate.

B) CORRECT:

In approximately 25% of cases, eclampsia occurs hours to days after birth. The treatment is the same as for antepartum eclampsia and focuses on anticonvulsive therapy in the form of IV magnesium sulfate. If the patient does not improve, lorazepam can be added to the therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid can be used in the treatment of seizures and epilepsy. However, it is not the treatment of choice in postpartum eclampsia.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine is indicated for the treatment of severe hypertension. Even though this patient does have hypertension, it is not considered severe (> 160/110 mm Hg). As such, treatment needs to focus on her tonic-clonic seizures.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin can be used in the treatment of seizures and epilepsy and is generally considered safe even while breastfeeding. However, it is not used in the treatment of eclampsia.
questions.hint: This woman presents with generalized tonic-clonic seizures several hours after the birth of her first child, with a neurological examination notable for hyperreflexia and clonus. These findings together with a history of headache, blurry vision, and abdominal pain are severe warning signs for postpartum eclampsia.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 14 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a routine prenatal visit. She feels well. Her other children were delivered vaginally at term after uncomplicated pregnancies. She has chronic hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include methyldopa, insulin, and a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. Examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 16-week gestation. Her hemoglobin A1c is 5.9%. Results from a quadruple screening test and 24-hour urine collection show no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a dichorionic twin pregnancy without evidence of fetal abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management at this time?

choices.text: No further management is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Monthly prenatal check-ups alone are indicated for patients with an uncomplicated multifetal pregnancy at < 28 weeks' gestation. This patient, however, has multiple risk factors for preeclampsia, making another step necessary.

B) CORRECT:

Prophylactic low-dose aspirin in the second and third trimesters is indicated in all pregnant women with a high risk of developing preeclampsia, as seen here. Other risk factors for preeclampsia include previous preeclampsia, chronic kidney disease, obesity, and thrombophilia (e.g., antiphospholipid syndrome). The initial workup of patients at high risk of developing preeclampsia should include a 24-hour urine collection to assess the baseline kidney function. In addition to low-dose aspirin and routine prenatal care, blood pressure and laboratory values (e.g., platelet count, creatinine, urinary protein, liver chemistry, HbA1c) should be monitored closely. As an increased risk of preeclampsia also confers an increased risk of placental insufficiency, frequent fetal monitoring with ultrasound to assess fetal growth is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

A nonstress test (NST) checks for fetal oxygenation and is indicated in high-risk pregnancies (e.g., individuals with gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, uteroplacental insufficiency), for which this patient has multiple risk factors. However, an NST should not be performed before 26–28 weeks' gestation because the fetal nervous system is not mature enough to enable fetal heart rate acceleration. This patient is only at 14 weeks' gestation, making another step more appropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing the insulin dosage is appropriate in pregnant patients with type 2 or gestational diabetes mellitus, and elevated hemoglobin A1c. This patient's hemoglobin A1c of 5.9% is already within the recommended range of < 6%. Increasing the insulin dosage would put this patient at risk for hypoglycemia.
questions.hint: Advanced maternal age, chronic hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and multifetal gestation are risk factors for developing preeclampsia.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 37 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit. She feels well. She states that she did not follow up with her gynecologist on a regular basis due to a busy work schedule. Pregnancy and delivery of her first two children were uncomplicated. Her blood pressure was 127/75 mm Hg at her initial obstetrics appointment. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 37-week gestation. Physical examination shows 2+ edema in the lower extremities. Urinalysis shows:


Blood
negative


Protein
3+


RBC
1–2/hpf


RBC casts
negative


After four hours of observation, her vital signs are unchanged. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with new-onset hypertension (145/95 mm Hg) and proteinuria (3+ protein on urinalysis), which, after 20 weeks' gestation, is sufficient to diagnose preeclampsia without severe features. Since severe features (such as severe hypertension, headache, pulmonary edema) can develop quickly, labor should be induced at ≥ 37 weeks of gestation in order to minimize adverse maternal outcomes without worsening neonatal outcomes. Preeclampsia without severe features that develops prior to 34 weeks is usually managed conservatively until delivery at 37 weeks; earlier delivery is generally not recommended due to the high risk of complications of prematurity.

Key learning point: Preeclampsia without severe features at or beyond 37 weeks’ gestation is managed by inducing labor to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Dexamethasone is used to lower the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants < 34 weeks' gestation. There is no evidence showing risk reduction at 37 weeks' gestation, nor would neonatal RDS be expected at this age.

C) INCORRECT:

Methyldopa is the first-line treatment for severe gestational hypertension. There is no clear evidence for its effectiveness in treating mild hypertension (140–150/90–100 mm Hg). Furthermore, this patient does not only have new-onset hypertension, but also proteinuria, which is consistent with the diagnosis of preeclampsia.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has new-onset hypertension (145/95 mm Hg) and proteinuria, which is consistent with a diagnosis of preeclampsia without severe features. Since preeclampsia can be a progressive disease that can lead to severe hypertension, end-organ damage, eclampsia, seizures, and death, reassurance would not be the most appropriate next step in management.

E) INCORRECT:

Electronic fetal monitoring with continuous CTG is a method of assessing fetal health during delivery. This patient has new-onset hypertension (145/95 mm Hg) and proteinuria, which is consistent with a diagnosis of preeclampsia without features of severe disease. Although this places the fetus at a higher risk of adverse events, continuous monitoring is typically only used in the intrapartum period to identify abnormal fetal heart tracings. There is no evidence supporting the use of continuous CTG in the antepartum period. Typically, fetal health in the antepartum period is assessed via fetal movement counts, weekly (or twice weekly) nonstress testing, and/or biophysical profiles.
questions.hint: This patient presents with hypertension and proteinuria. In the absence of further symptoms, this is consistent with the diagnosis of preeclampsia without severe features.

questions.text: A 36-year-old primigravid woman presents for a prenatal visit at 14 weeks' gestation. She has had episodic headaches over the past month. At home, blood pressure measurements have ranged from 134/82 mm Hg to 148/94 mm Hg. Today, her blood pressure is 146/91 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 13-week gestation. Her platelet count is 320,000/mm3, serum creatinine is 0.8 mg/dL, and serum ALT is 17 U/L. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The onset of hypertension before 20 weeks' gestation, prior to pregnancy, or persisting beyond 6 weeks postpartum, is known as chronic or preexisting hypertension and is not due to the pregnancy itself. Complications of hypertension in pregnancy include fetal growth restriction, preterm birth, placental abruption, and superimposed preeclampsia.

First-line agents for medical treatment of hypertension during pregnancy include labetalol, hydralazine, nifedipine, and methyldopa. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin-receptor blockers are contraindicated during pregnancy because of their teratogenic effects.

B) INCORRECT:

Gestational hypertension can only be diagnosed if the onset of hypertension is after 20 weeks' gestation. In a patient at 14 weeks' gestation, a different diagnosis must be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

By definition, eclampsia involves the occurrence of grand mal seizures and/or coma. This patient is conscious, alert, oriented, and has no history of convulsions.

D) INCORRECT:

Isolated systolic hypertension is characterized by elevated systolic BP and normal diastolic BP (and widened pulse pressure), which is usually the result of decreased arterial compliance. This patient's diastolic BP, which is > 90 mm Hg, is not consistent with isolated systolic hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Preeclampsia is a complication of pregnancy characterized by new-onset hypertension plus either proteinuria or significant end-organ dysfunction after 20 weeks' gestation. This patient, however, has a normal urinalysis, normal blood test results, and no clinical evidence of end-organ damage. In addition, she is only at 14 weeks' gestation.
questions.hint: A few episodes of headache are quite common during the first trimester because of changes in maternal hormones.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 29 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department 1 day after the sudden onset of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She had preeclampsia during her last pregnancy. She spent 2 weeks in Myanmar 1 month ago. She appears tired. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 182/102 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.0 g/dL


Platelet count
90,000/mm3


Serum



Glucose (fasting)
97 mg/dL


Total bilirubin
2.5 mg/dL


Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT)
740 U/L


Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT)
705 U/L


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets indicating a diagnosis of HELLP syndrome, a complication of pregnancy that most commonly develops during the third trimester. HELLP syndrome causes acute-onset abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, hypertension, hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, hyperbilirubinemia, and transaminitis. It is considered a variant or complication of preeclampsia. Management of HELLP syndrome includes administration of magnesium sulfate (to prevent maternal seizures), maternal stabilization (e.g., with antihypertensive therapy), and prompt delivery.

B) INCORRECT:

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) can cause thrombocytopenia and has a higher incidence among patients who are pregnant. However, it does not typically cause abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, hypertension, hemolytic anemia, hyperbilirubinemia, or transaminitis. ITP can rarely occur in association with autoimmune hemolytic anemia (Evans syndrome), but this condition results in spherocytes on peripheral blood smear, not schistocytes.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis E infection can cause acute-onset right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, hyperbilirubinemia, and transaminitis as a result of hepatic injury, which is often more severe if the infection occurs during the third trimester of pregnancy. This patient's history of recent travel to Asia, where hepatitis E infection is endemic, further raises suspicion for this diagnosis. However, it is uncommon for hepatitis E infection to cause hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia. Moreover, severe infections typically cause fever and hypotension (from sepsis) rather than severe hypertension, as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) can cause abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, hyperbilirubinemia, and transaminitis. However, this condition usually develops with several days of progressive symptoms, in contrast to this patient's sudden onset of symptoms. In addition, the serum transaminase concentrations associated with TTP are not typically as elevated as those in this patient. Moreover, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of TTP, such as fever and neurologic symptoms (e.g., confusion, headache, focal deficits).

E) INCORRECT:

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) most commonly occurs during the third trimester and can cause acute-onset abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, hypertension, hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, hyperbilirubinemia, and transaminitis. However, this patient does not have other features of AFLP (e.g., hypoglycemia, encephalopathy). In addition, AFLP does not typically cause severe hypertension.
questions.hint: A peripheral blood smear would show schistocytes, which are fragments of red blood cells created by hemolysis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravid woman at 18 weeks' gestation presents with a new headache. She has a history of hypertension, which was previously controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. However, she discontinued this medication before her pregnancy and opted to implement lifestyle changes alone to control her hypertension. Despite adherence to dietary and exercise recommendations, she has had consistently high blood-pressure measurements. Her pulse is 98/min and blood pressure is 168/99 mm Hg in the right arm while she is seated; repeat measurement is 171/102 mm Hg. Which one of the following antihypertensive treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) have been associated with fetal growth restriction, developmental abnormalities, and fetal death; they are contraindicated in pregnancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin II-receptor antagonists (e.g., losartan) have been associated with fetal growth restriction, developmental abnormalities, and fetal death; they are contraindicated in pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, have been shown to be relatively safe in pregnancy. However, this class of drugs is not typically recommended as first-line treatment because it may reduce plasma and amniotic-fluid volume. Diuretics are usually reserved for patients who have persistent hypertension despite maximal doses of labetalol and nifedipine.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic hypertension, a common problem in pregnancy, increases the risk for adverse pregnancy outcomes for both mother and fetus. Effective control of hypertension during pregnancy reduces the risk for maternal end-organ damage and pregnancy-aggravated hypertensive episodes but not preeclampsia, placental abruption, fetal growth restriction, or fetal death.

Methyldopa was traditionally considered a first-line antihypertensive agent in pregnancy, given extensive research supporting its safety in this setting. However, it has fallen out of favor in recent years because it is less effective than other agents, and adverse effects such as maternal somnolence limit its tolerability. In addition, manufacturers have discontinued the production of methyldopa, leading to difficulty in accessing the medication. As a result, current guidelines recommend either labetalol or nifedipine as first-line antihypertensive agents in pregnant patients. Labetalol, an alpha- and beta-adrenergic antagonist, has been shown to reduce blood pressure and appears to be safe in pregnancy; it is the most appropriate choice for this patient, although nifedipine would also be acceptable.

Key learning point: The most appropriate options for treating uncontrolled hypertension during the second trimester of pregnancy are labetalol and nifedipine.

E) INCORRECT:

Pure beta-blockers, such as atenolol, are more likely to cause fetal growth restriction than some other agents and are not recommended in pregnancy.
questions.hint: The target blood pressure in pregnancy is <140/100 mm Hg in the absence of preexisting end-organ damage — or lower if chronic kidney disease is present.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She reports that she has had frequent headaches and dizziness recently. Her blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 32-week gestation and fetal heart rate is 155/min. The patient's serum creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL, aspartate aminotransferase is 35 U/L and platelet count is 60,000/mm3. The patient is diagnosed with preeclampsia with severe features, and treatment with labetalol and intravenous infusion of magnesium sulfate is initiated. Three hours later, physical examination shows absent deep tendon reflexes bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue magnesium sulfate and administer calcium gluconate
Discontinue magnesium sulfate and administer lorazepam

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

IV infusion of magnesium sulfate is administered in preeclampsia with severe features to prevent progression to eclampsia. Any patient receiving magnesium sulfate should be closely monitored, as magnesium sulfate can have severe side effects. One of the first signs of magnesium sulfate toxicity is depressed or absent deep tendon reflexes. If left untreated, the toxicity can progress to respiratory depression and even cardiac arrest. The first step in managing magnesium sulfate toxicity would be decreasing the dose of the infusion. However, the absence of deep tendon reflexes indicates more severe toxicity that requires stopping the infusion and administering calcium gluconate.

B) INCORRECT:

Labetalol lowers heart rate and blood pressure but does not affect the deep tendon reflexes. Stopping labetalol would therefore worsen her preeclampsia, without addressing her current complaints (depressed deep tendon reflexes), which most likely arise from magnesium sulfate toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Absent or depressed deep tendon reflexes are a sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity. If left untreated, the toxicity can progress to respiratory depression and even cardiac arrest. Lorazepam, like all benzodiazepines, causes muscle relaxation and would, therefore, further depress not only the deep tendon reflexes but also respiration. It is therefore absolutely contraindicated in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's absent deep tendon reflexes are a sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity, which would not be treated by delivery. Delivery is the only curative option in preeclampsia. However, emergency delivery is only indicated for stable patients with severe sequelae of preeclampsia, including eclampsia, pulmonary edema, DIC, abruptio placentae, intrauterine fetal demise, or uncontrollable severe hypertension. This patient does not exhibit any of these conditions. Instead of delivery, the goal in the management of preeclampsia in this patient at 32 weeks' gestation is to stabilize the mother and fetus until at least 34 weeks' gestation and to then deliver the child. In some cases, complications may arise in which delivery is indicated before 34 weeks' gestation, but only after corticosteroid therapy for 48 hours (to promote neonatal maturation). In such cases, if feasible, vaginal delivery would be preferred over C-section.

E) INCORRECT:

Absent or depressed deep tendon reflexes, as seen in this patient, are a sign of magnesium sulfate toxicity. Further increasing the dose could result in respiratory and cardiac arrest and is, therefore, absolutely contraindicated!
questions.hint: All patients receiving magnesium need close monitoring (including continuous telemetry) for signs of hypermagnesemia.

questions.text: A 36-year-old primigravid woman at 34 weeks' gestation comes to the office because of a 1-week history of upper abdominal discomfort, nausea, and malaise. She had a mild upper respiratory tract infection a week ago. She has a 3-year history of hypertension treated with labetalol. Pulse is 92/min and blood pressure is 147/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a nontender uterus consistent in size with a 34-week gestation. There is mild tenderness of the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. The fetal heart rate is reactive with no decelerations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Serum transaminase levels and platelet count

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum bile acid levels would be an important diagnostic marker for intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy. This rare condition usually occurs in patients at ≥ 30 weeks of gestation. But patients with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy usually report severe pruritus, and the condition is not associated with hypertension, making this condition a very unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum amylase and lipase levels would be an important diagnostic marker for acute pancreatitis, which also causes upper abdominal discomfort and malaise. But the classic presentation of acute pancreatitis is constant, severe epigastric pain that classically radiates towards the back, which is not the case in this patient. She also does not mention that the pain gets worse after meals and when supine, nor does she have fever or vomiting, which would be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc serology is the classic screening test when suspecting hepatitis B. Acute hepatitis B infection is often asymptomatic. If it is symptomatic, it can cause fever, fatigue, nausea, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain. Considering hepatits B has an incubation period of 1–6 months, she would have had to become infected during her pregnancy. But the patient is not known to be at high risk of hepatitis B (as would be the case in e.g., drug users or health care workers) and her abdominal discomfort is not specific to the RUQ, making this a less likely diagnosis. Lastly, given this patient's history of hypertension, another potentially life-threatening diagnosis must be ruled out first.

D) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up would be adequate if her malaise had been caused by the preceding viral, respiratory infection. But there is no way to ascertain that and as such all causes of upper abdominal discomfort that can negatively affect the outcome of the pregnancy must be considered. As such, more diagnostic steps are necessary.

E) CORRECT:

Checking the serum transaminase levels and platelet count is a good diagnostic test when suspecting hypertensive pregnancy disorders, such as preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome. Even though the clinical findings in this patient are subtle, hypertension and abdominal pain in a woman at ≥ 34 weeks of gestation should always prompt evaluation for hypertensive pregnancy disorders. Elevated transaminases (indicating impaired liver function) and reduced platelets would indicate HELLP syndrome. Other possible findings in both preeclampsia and HELLP are headache, visual disturbances, proteinuria, and severe hypertension (systolic ≥ 160 mmHg or diastolic BP ≥ 110 mmHg).
questions.hint: A history of recent-onset abdominal pain or discomfort in a pregnant woman, especially in the third trimester of a woman with hypertension should arouse suspicion of HELLP syndrome.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 28 weeks' gestation presents for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F) and blood pressure is 165/115 mm Hg. Her blood pressure measured 5 hours ago at home was 160/112 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 28-week gestation. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and hepatic transaminases are within the reference ranges. Urinalysis is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril and angiotensin receptor blockers are absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy because they can cause permanent renal damage in the fetus as well as congenital malformations of the cardiovascular system and/or CNS.

B) INCORRECT:

Strenuous exercise (e.g., weight lifting, high-intensity interval training) should be avoided in patients with preeclampsia. However, mild exercise (e.g., walking, stretching) may be beneficial in this patient group. Complete bed rest is associated with an increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and is therefore not recommended in patients with hypertensive pregnancy disorders.

C) INCORRECT:

Dietary modifications such as reduction of salt intake and a DASH diet are recommended for all patients with primary hypertension. However, they have not been shown to improve outcomes in patients with gestational hypertension, which is primarily due to placental angiogenic factors that negatively affect maternal endothelial function.

D) INCORRECT:

Low-dose aspirin can be initiated after 12 weeks' gestation to reduce the risk of preeclampsia in patients with certain high-risk features, such as a history of preeclampsia in a previous pregnancy, multiple pregnancy, diabetes mellitus (gestational or nongestational), preexisting hypertension, and/or autoimmune diseases. This patient already meets the diagnostic criteria for preeclampsia with severe features. Aspirin is solely used in the prophylaxis but not in the treatment of preeclampsia.

E) CORRECT:

Antihypertensive therapy should be initiated as soon as possible in patients with preeclampsia with severe features. Available options include intravenous hydralazine, intravenous labetalol, and oral nifedipine. Magnesium sulfate should also be administered for seizure prophylaxis. Patients between 24 weeks' and 34 weeks' gestation should also receive antenatal corticosteroid therapy for fetal maturation.

Management of patients with preeclampsia with severe features who are at < 34 weeks' gestation should be continued on an inpatient basis. Although expectant management is acceptable in these patients, delivery should not be delayed if there is maternal or fetal deterioration.
questions.hint: Preeclampsia with severe features can be diagnosed in patients at > 20 weeks' gestation who present with systolic blood pressure ≥ 160 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 110 mm Hg, even if other abnormalities characteristic of preeclampsia are absent on clinical or diagnostic evaluation.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old G2P1 woman at 33 weeks of gestation presents with worsening headaches and intermittent blurred vision for the past two days, along with dull right upper quadrant pain. She reports the headaches worsen at night and she occasionally sees bright spots. She has mild pedal edema but denies any seizures. She feels the fetus is moving normally (see lab results).

Blood pressure
160/96 mmHg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Platelet count
180 x 109/L
150 - 400 x 109/L


Alanine aminotransferase
60 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
48 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L


Urine




 Protein
Present
Absent



Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eclampsia requires the occurrence of seizures in addition to symptoms of preeclampsia, such as hypertension and neurological disturbances. Although the patient presents with headache and blurred vision, the absence of seizures excludes eclampsia as a diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

HELLP syndrome is characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. Although the patient has right upper quadrant pain and mildly elevated liver enzymes, the normal platelet count and lack of hemolysis markers, such as elevated lactate dehydrogenase, do not support this diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Preeclampsia with severe features manifests in pregnant patients with new-onset hypertension and proteinuria, accompanied by symptoms such as headache, blurred vision, and right upper quadrant pain. These symptoms indicate significant multisystem involvement, including neurologic and hepatic systems. The mild elevation in liver enzymes and right upper quadrant pain suggest hepatic involvement. The pathophysiology involves abnormal placentation leading to endothelial dysfunction, vasoconstriction, and target organ ischemia. The presence of these clinical and laboratory findings supports the diagnosis of preeclampsia with severe features.

Key learning point: Preeclampsia is characterized by hypertension and signs of end-organ dysfunction such as headache, visual disturbances, and abdominal pain, and should be considered in pregnant women presenting with these symptoms after 20 weeks of gestation.

D) INCORRECT:

Gestational hypertension is defined by new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation without proteinuria or systemic involvement. The presence of proteinuria, headache, blurred vision, and right upper quadrant pain indicates systemic involvement, which is inconsistent with gestational hypertension.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman at 32 weeks' gestation presents with a two-week history of headaches and swelling in her feet. She reports no history of chronic hypertension. Physical exam shows mild bilateral lower extremity edema without upper abdominal pain. Routine laboratory evaluation reveals increased protein excretion.

Blood pressure
150/95 mm Hg to 160/100 mm Hg

Which diagnosis best explains her current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gestational hypertension involves elevated blood pressure after 20 weeks of gestation without proteinuria or significant end-organ involvement. The presence of proteinuria in this patient differentiates her condition from gestational hypertension, as proteinuria is not expected in isolated gestational hypertension.

B) CORRECT:

Preeclampsia manifests with new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive patient, accompanied by proteinuria or signs of end-organ dysfunction. This patient presents with elevated blood pressure and proteinuria, meeting the diagnostic criteria for preeclampsia. Headaches may indicate cerebral involvement due to systemic endothelial dysfunction, while peripheral edema results from increased capillary permeability. The underlying pathophysiology involves abnormal placental implantation, leading to reduced uteroplacental perfusion and an imbalance of angiogenic factors. These factors contribute to the multisystem effects observed in preeclampsia, aligning with the patient's clinical and laboratory findings.

Key learning point: Preeclampsia is diagnosed by new-onset hypertension and proteinuria after 20 weeks of gestation, often accompanied by symptoms such as headache.

C) INCORRECT:

HELLP syndrome is characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count, often with right upper quadrant pain. This patient lacks upper abdominal pain, abnormal liver function tests, and thrombocytopenia, making HELLP syndrome unlikely. Her presentation aligns more with preeclampsia.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic hypertension is characterized by high blood pressure present before 20 weeks of gestation or predating pregnancy. This patient lacks a history of hypertension, and her symptoms, including proteinuria, began in the third trimester, indicating an acute change rather than a chronic condition.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G1P0 woman at 32 weeks’ gestation presents to the clinic with elevated blood pressure measured at 146/92 mmHg on two separate occasions one week apart. She denies headaches, visual disturbances, or epigastric pain. She has no history of chronic hypertension or renal disease and is otherwise healthy, taking no medications. Physical examination is normal. Laboratory results show normal liver function tests, platelet count of 280 × 10^9/L, and normal serum creatinine. Urinalysis shows no protein. Fetal growth assessment is appropriate for gestational age.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Gestational hypertension is characterized by new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks' gestation without proteinuria or end-organ damage. This patient has blood pressure readings of 146/92 mmHg on two occasions, meeting the criteria for hypertension. The absence of proteinuria, normal liver function tests, platelet count, and serum creatinine indicate no systemic involvement, differentiating it from preeclampsia. Understanding these criteria is crucial for monitoring and managing gestational hypertension.

Key learning point: Gestational hypertension is characterized by new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation without proteinuria or severe features, distinguishing it from preeclampsia.

B) INCORRECT:

Preeclampsia without severe features requires new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks' gestation with either proteinuria or end-organ damage. This patient lacks proteinuria and has normal liver function, platelet count, and serum creatinine, excluding preeclampsia.

C) INCORRECT:

White coat hypertension involves elevated blood pressure in clinical settings but normal readings elsewhere. This patient has persistent hypertension on two separate occasions, with no evidence of normal out-of-office readings, making white coat hypertension unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic hypertension is defined as hypertension present before pregnancy or before 20 weeks' gestation. This patient has no history of hypertension, and her elevated blood pressure was first noted at 32 weeks, indicating a pregnancy-specific onset.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of new-onset headache and mild swelling in her hands and feet. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows a reassuring, reactive tracing. She denies right upper-quadrant pain (see lab results).

Blood pressure
150/95 mmHg to 156/100 mmHg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 24-hour urine protein
2600 mg/day
0 - 150 mg/day


Platelet count
190 x 10⁹/L
150 - 400 x 10⁹/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
65 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L


Creatinine
79 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Outpatient follow-up with weekly laboratory surveillance
Admission for close maternal and fetal monitoring

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous labetalol is used for severe hypertension (≥160/110 mmHg) to prevent complications. This patient's blood pressure is moderately elevated, not reaching emergency levels. Immediate IV labetalol is unnecessary and could reduce uteroplacental perfusion without severe hypertension or end-organ compromise.

B) INCORRECT:

Outpatient follow-up is suitable for mild preeclampsia without concerning features. However, this patient has significant proteinuria, elevated blood pressure, a new-onset headache, and elevated AST, indicating severe preeclampsia. These findings necessitate inpatient monitoring due to the risk of rapid deterioration.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with preeclampsia, characterized by new-onset hypertension and significant proteinuria after 20 weeks' gestation. Her blood pressure readings and 24-hour urine protein excretion confirm the diagnosis. The new-onset headache and elevated aspartate aminotransferase (AST) suggest potential progression to severe preeclampsia. At 32 weeks' gestation, the fetus is preterm, making immediate delivery undesirable unless conditions worsen. Admission allows for intensive monitoring of maternal and fetal status, enabling timely interventions such as antihypertensives and magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis if needed. This approach balances the risks of continuing the pregnancy with potential prematurity complications.

Key learning point: In cases of preeclampsia at 32 weeks gestation, admission for observation is crucial to monitor the mother and fetus and to determine the appropriate timing for delivery.

D) INCORRECT:

While delivery is the definitive treatment for preeclampsia, immediate induction at 32 weeks with reassuring fetal monitoring poses risks of prematurity. The patient has preeclampsia with some severe features but stable platelet count and renal function. Expectant management with antihypertensives, magnesium sulfate, and corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity is preferred unless maternal or fetal conditions worsen.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 38 weeks’ gestation is brought to the Emergency Department by her husband after experiencing a short generalized tonic-clonic seizure at home. On arrival, she is disoriented and complains of a severe headache. The fetal heart rate is reassuring, and there is no active vaginal bleeding (see lab results).

Blood pressure
176/108 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 Protein
3+
Absent


Platelet count
110 x 109/L
150 - 400 x 109/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
85 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L



After securing the airway and ensuring adequate oxygenation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous phenytoin is used for seizures due to epilepsy but does not address the pathophysiology of eclamptic seizures, which involve cerebral edema and endothelial dysfunction. Magnesium sulfate is preferred as it stabilizes neuronal membranes and addresses the vascular and metabolic derangements in eclampsia.

B) INCORRECT:

While delivery is the definitive management for severe hypertensive complications of pregnancy, immediate cesarean delivery in a patient with active seizures and hemodynamic instability increases surgical risks. Stabilizing the patient's neurologic and cardiovascular status with magnesium sulfate is prioritized before proceeding to delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous diazepam can acutely terminate seizures but does not address the underlying pathophysiology of eclampsia, which involves endothelial dysfunction and systemic disturbances. Its short duration of action and potential for respiratory depression make it suboptimal compared to magnesium sulfate in this context.

D) CORRECT:

Eclampsia is characterized by new-onset generalized tonic-clonic seizures in a patient with preeclampsia. After airway stabilization, preventing further seizures is crucial. Intravenous magnesium sulfate is the first-line treatment, acting as an anticonvulsant by antagonizing NMDA receptors. It reduces recurrent seizures when administered as an initial bolus followed by a maintenance infusion. This approach is essential in severe cases with laboratory findings such as proteinuria, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes, alongside hypertension, to stabilize the patient before definitive management with delivery.

Key learning point: In the management of eclampsia, the immediate priority is to prevent further seizures using magnesium sulfate, which is the drug of choice for seizure prophylaxis and treatment in eclampsia.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to Obstetric Triage with severe right upper quadrant pain for 8 hours. She reports persistent headaches and mild visual changes for the past two days. Examination reveals pronounced right upper quadrant tenderness (see lab results and report).

Blood pressure
160/95 mmHg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Platelet count
75 x 109/L
150 - 400 x 109/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
288 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L


Lactate dehydrogenase
680 IU/L
60 - 160 IU/L



Peripheral blood smear: Fragmented red blood cells
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous magnesium sulfate infusion and reevaluation in 48 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids may modify lab abnormalities in HELLP syndrome or enhance fetal lung maturity in preterm gestations. However, at 36 weeks, the fetus is mature, and corticosteroids do not alter the maternal course of severe disease. Immediate delivery is necessary to address the maternal condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine treats severe hypertension but does not address the multi-system involvement in HELLP syndrome, including hepatic and hematologic derangements. Blood pressure control alone is insufficient, as the condition requires prompt delivery to stabilize the patient.

C) CORRECT:

The patient presents with HELLP syndrome, a severe form of preeclampsia characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. Symptoms include right upper quadrant pain, headaches, and visual changes, indicating significant maternal compromise. At 36 weeks of gestation, immediate delivery is the definitive treatment to prevent further maternal complications. Delivery removes the placenta, addressing the underlying pathophysiology and halting the progression of systemic endothelial injury.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected HELLP syndrome in a pregnant woman, the most appropriate management is emergent delivery to resolve the condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Magnesium sulfate is used for seizure prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia but does not address the hemolysis, liver injury, or thrombocytopenia seen in HELLP syndrome. Reevaluating in 48 hours is inappropriate due to the rapid progression of the condition, which requires immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 18 weeks’ gestation presents with poorly controlled hypertension despite lifestyle changes. Which agent should be avoided to prevent fetal complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, disrupts fetal renal development by affecting the renin-angiotensin system. It is linked to fetal complications such as oligohydramnios and renal dysgenesis, especially in the second and third trimesters. Other antihypertensives like labetalol, nifedipine, and methyldopa are safer alternatives for managing hypertension during pregnancy.

Key learning point: ACE inhibitors like lisinopril are contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of fetal harm, while labetalol, nifedipine, and methyldopa are considered safe for managing hypertension in pregnant women.

B) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, lowers blood pressure by causing vasodilation without significantly affecting uteroplacental blood flow. It is considered safe during pregnancy, particularly in the second trimester, and is not associated with the teratogenic risks of ACE inhibitors.

C) INCORRECT:

Labetalol, a combined alpha and beta-adrenergic blocker, is a first-line treatment for hypertension in pregnancy. It effectively reduces blood pressure while maintaining uteroplacental blood flow, with a proven safety profile in the second and third trimesters.

D) INCORRECT:

Methyldopa, a central alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, is a standard antihypertensive in pregnancy due to its favorable fetal safety profile. It does not affect fetal renal development, making it a suitable choice for managing hypertension in pregnant patients.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 woman at 33 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with worsening headache, right upper quadrant pain, and decreased fetal movements over the past 24 hours. She has moderate edema in her lower extremities and 3+ protein on dipstick. Pelvic examination reveals a cervix dilated to 2 cm and 80% effaced. A non-stress test shows reassuring fetal heart tracings (see lab results).

Blood pressure
165/110 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Platelet count
80 x 10⁹/L
150 - 400 x 10⁹/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
190 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L


Lactate dehydrogenase
650 IU/L
60 - 160 IU/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Expectant management with daily inpatient laboratory monitoring
Immediate cesarean delivery without trial of labor
Intravenous labetalol alone to control blood pressure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Expectant management is inappropriate due to the severe hypertensive disorder and HELLP syndrome features, including severe hypertension, elevated liver enzymes, and thrombocytopenia. These findings increase the risk of maternal complications, necessitating prompt delivery. The cervical dilation and effacement further indicate that expectant management would delay necessary intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate cesarean delivery is not indicated as the cervix is 2 cm dilated and 80% effaced, and fetal heart tracings are reassuring. A trial of labor is appropriate given the favorable cervical status, minimizing risks associated with surgical delivery. Cesarean delivery is reserved for nonreassuring fetal status or contraindications to labor, which are absent here.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous labetalol effectively manages severe hypertension in pregnancy but is insufficient alone in this patient. The patient exhibits severe preeclampsia with HELLP syndrome, requiring comprehensive management, including magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis and prompt delivery. Relying solely on labetalol neglects the need for addressing the underlying condition and associated risks.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with severe preeclampsia and features of HELLP syndrome, including hypertension, headache, right upper quadrant pain, thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and hemolysis. These findings necessitate prompt delivery, the definitive treatment for severe preeclampsia. The cervix is 2 cm dilated and 80% effaced, indicating a favorable condition for labor induction. Intravenous oxytocin facilitates uterine contractions for vaginal delivery, reducing maternal morbidity compared to cesarean delivery. Maternal stabilization, including magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis and antihypertensive therapy, is essential, but delivery is prioritized once the maternal condition is stable.

Key learning point: In cases of severe preeclampsia at 33 weeks' gestation, immediate delivery is often necessary to prevent maternal and fetal complications, with induction of labor being a viable option if the cervix is favorable and there are no contraindications.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old G2P1 woman at 35 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of severe headache and visual disturbances. She reports decreased fetal movement over the past day. Urinalysis shows 3+ protein. Laboratory results reveal a platelet count of 190 × 10^9/L with normal liver enzymes. An obstetric ultrasound confirms a viable fetus with a normal amniotic fluid index. After initial management to control her blood pressure, she remains at risk for severe complications, including seizures.

Blood pressure
170/110 mmHg

Which of the following measures is most appropriate to prevent eclamptic seizures in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antihypertensive agents manage chronic hypertension in pregnancy but have a delayed onset and do not directly modulate neuronal excitability. In severe preeclampsia, the primary concern is cerebral and endothelial dysfunction leading to seizures, not just high blood pressure. Therefore, oral antihypertensives are not effective for seizure prevention in this context.

B) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines have anticonvulsant properties but are not validated for preventing seizures in severe preeclampsia. The condition involves complex mechanisms like endothelial dysfunction and cerebral edema, which benzodiazepines do not address. Their use may cause excessive sedation without proven efficacy in preventing eclamptic seizures.

C) CORRECT:

Magnesium sulfate is the preferred treatment for seizure prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. It works by antagonizing N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors, reducing excitatory neurotransmission, and stabilizing neuronal membranes. Severe preeclampsia, characterized by hypertension and neurological symptoms like severe headache and visual disturbances, poses a high risk for progression to eclampsia. The standard regimen includes a loading dose followed by a maintenance infusion, with monitoring of deep tendon reflexes and respiratory status to prevent toxicity. Magnesium sulfate significantly reduces seizure risk and improves maternal outcomes in severe preeclampsia.

Key learning point: In a pregnant patient presenting with symptoms of preeclampsia at 35 weeks, the administration of magnesium sulfate is crucial to prevent seizures.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids are used to promote fetal lung maturity before 34 weeks of gestation. In severe preeclampsia, seizures are not mediated by inflammatory processes that corticosteroids address. At 35 weeks, fetal lung maturity is less of a concern, and corticosteroids do not prevent seizures in this context.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old G2P1 woman at 36 weeks gestation is admitted after experiencing two generalized tonic-clonic seizures. She reports severe headaches, epigastric pain, and visual disturbances for two days. Physical examination reveals hyperreflexia and mild confusion. She receives intravenous magnesium sulfate, and her seizures are controlled. Her blood pressure remains elevated despite intravenous labetalol. Fetal heart tracings are reassuring (see lab results).


Heart rate
90/min


Blood pressure
168/110 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
16/min




Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
115 g/L
120 - 160 g/L


Platelet count
120 x 109/L
150 - 400 x 109/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
42 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L


Creatinine
95 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Urine




 Protein
3+
Absent



What is the definitive management for her underlying condition?

choices.text: Initiate intravenous phenytoin for seizure prophylaxis
Prolong observation until blood pressure normalizes

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In eclampsia, the definitive management is delivery, which resolves the underlying placental pathology. This patient, at 36 weeks gestation, presents with seizures, severe hypertension, and laboratory abnormalities indicative of eclampsia. Delivery at this gestational age benefits fetal maturity and prevents further maternal complications, such as cerebral hemorrhage and multi-organ dysfunction. Delivery interrupts the cascade of endothelial dysfunction caused by the ischemic placenta. Supportive measures, including magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis and antihypertensives for blood pressure control, are adjuncts to this definitive intervention.

Key learning point: In cases of eclampsia, the definitive treatment is delivery after maternal stabilization, with magnesium sulfate being the first-line treatment for seizures.

B) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin is not effective for eclampsia, where seizures result from a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy. Magnesium sulfate is the preferred treatment for stopping and preventing seizures in this context, as it addresses the vascular and endothelial dysfunction associated with eclampsia.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnesium sulfate is crucial for seizure prophylaxis in eclampsia but does not address the underlying placental pathology. The patient's severe disease, with neurologic involvement and persistent hypertension, requires delivery to resolve the condition. Continuing magnesium sulfate alone does not eliminate the pathologic state.

D) INCORRECT:

Prolonged observation ignores the underlying placental pathology driving the severe clinical features, including seizures and hypertension. Blood pressure control is important, but delivery is necessary to address the root cause and prevent further maternal and fetal complications.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 woman at 10 weeks’ gestation presents to the Outpatient Clinic for prenatal care. Her previous pregnancy was complicated by early-onset preeclampsia requiring delivery at 34 weeks. She has no other comorbid conditions. Her vital signs are stable. Physical examination is normal, and initial laboratory tests are within normal ranges.
Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to decrease her likelihood of recurrence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium supplementation is beneficial in populations with low dietary calcium intake. This patient has normal laboratory findings and no indicators of calcium deficiency, making supplementation less appropriate for preventing recurrent preeclampsia.

B) INCORRECT:

Strict bed rest does not reduce the risk of recurrent preeclampsia and may lead to adverse outcomes like venous thromboembolism and muscle deconditioning. It does not address the underlying placental and endothelial abnormalities in preeclampsia.

C) CORRECT:

Low-dose aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase, reducing thromboxane A2 production and decreasing platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction. This shifts the balance toward prostacyclin, enhancing uteroplacental blood flow. Preeclampsia involves abnormal placental development and endothelial dysfunction. Initiating low-dose aspirin before 16 weeks' gestation optimizes placental development, reducing recurrence risk. Aspirin's role in enhancing placental vascularization and reducing inflammatory and thrombotic pathways aligns with its prophylactic use in high-risk pregnancies.

Key learning point: Low-dose aspirin is recommended for pregnant women at high risk of preeclampsia to reduce the risk of preeclampsia and fetal growth restriction.

D) INCORRECT:

Low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) is used to prevent thromboembolic events, not directly address abnormal placentation in preeclampsia. It benefits patients with thrombophilic conditions or antiphospholipid syndrome. This patient has a history of early-onset preeclampsia without thrombotic indicators, making LMWH inappropriate for preventing recurrence.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman at 36 weeks’ gestation presents to the clinic with persistent blood pressure readings exceeding 160/110 mm Hg, headache, and right upper quadrant discomfort. Laboratory studies reveal 3+ proteinuria and elevated serum creatinine. On examination, her reflexes are brisk, and she shows no seizure activity. She is started on intravenous magnesium sulfate.

Blood pressure
165/115 mm Hg

She inquires about the rationale behind lowering her blood pressure. Which of the following best explains the primary goal of antihypertensive therapy in her condition?

choices.text: Enhancing fetal well-being by improving placental perfusion
Reducing maternal risk of intracranial hemorrhage
Preventing eclampsia by directly stopping seizures
Prolonging gestation to reduce neonatal complications

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In severe preeclampsia, the primary goal is to control maternal blood pressure to prevent life-threatening complications. The pathological processes in preeclampsia already compromise placental perfusion, and aggressive blood pressure lowering could worsen fetal hypoxia.

B) CORRECT:

Severe preeclampsia is characterized by critically elevated blood pressures, increasing the risk of intracranial hemorrhage due to hemodynamic stress on cerebral vessels. Antihypertensive therapy aims to rapidly lower blood pressure, reducing stress on these vessels and minimizing the risk of hemorrhagic stroke. This approach prioritizes maternal health by preventing catastrophic complications while maintaining adequate placental perfusion.

Key learning point: In severe preeclampsia, antihypertensive medications are primarily used to decrease the risk of maternal complications such as stroke, rather than directly addressing fetal outcomes.

C) INCORRECT:

While eclampsia involves seizures in preeclampsia, magnesium sulfate, not antihypertensive therapy, is used to prevent seizures by reducing neuronal excitability. Antihypertensives primarily aim to reduce risks of acute cerebrovascular incidents, not directly prevent seizures.

D) INCORRECT:

In severe preeclampsia, maternal safety is the primary concern, not prolonging gestation. The patient has markers of severe preeclampsia, and the focus is on reducing maternal complications like stroke. At 36 weeks, the benefit of extending pregnancy is minimal compared to maternal risks.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 33 weeks gestation presents with persistent headaches, new-onset right upper quadrant pain, and 2 days of minimal urine output. She appears edematous with hyperreflexia. Dipstick reveals 3+ proteinuria (see lab results).

Blood pressure
170/110 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Alanine aminotransferase
70 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
90 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L


Platelet count
80 x 10⁹/L
150 - 400 x 10⁹/L



Which of the following best explains the decreased plasma volume observed in this patient?

choices.text: Excessive urine output due to acute tubular necrosis
Insufficient oral intake resulting in effective circulating volume depletion
Marked hypoalbuminemia from reduced hepatic production
Increased endothelial permeability causing fluid shift out of the vascular space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) typically involves a diuretic phase with increased urine output, not the oliguria seen here. ATN is often due to severe hypotension or nephrotoxic insults, which are not present. The patient's symptoms suggest endothelial dysfunction and capillary leak, not tubular injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Dehydration from insufficient oral intake typically presents with hypotension and tachycardia, not hypertension. The patient's symptoms align with a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy, where endothelial dysfunction causes capillary leak and relative intravascular volume contraction, unrelated to oral intake.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypoalbuminemia, which reduces oncotic pressure, is usually seen in chronic liver disease, not acute conditions like preeclampsia. The elevated transaminases and thrombocytopenia indicate acute liver injury, not reduced protein synthesis. The decreased plasma volume is due to increased vascular permeability, not hypoalbuminemia.

D) CORRECT:

In severe preeclampsia, systemic endothelial dysfunction leads to increased vascular permeability. This is mediated by factors like soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1 (sFlt-1), which antagonizes angiogenic signals. The resulting fluid shift from the intravascular compartment to interstitial spaces decreases plasma volume and causes edema. This vascular leak contributes to hypertension, proteinuria, and end-organ injury, which are characteristic of severe preeclampsia.

Key learning point: In severe preeclampsia, plasma volume is significantly decreased due to endothelial dysfunction and increased vascular permeability, leading to fluid shifts from the intravascular to the extravascular space.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 woman at 34 weeks’ gestation presents with headaches for the past week and mild ankle swelling. Examination shows pitting edema in both ankles (see lab results).

Blood pressure
148/94 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Platelet count
180 x 10⁹/L
150 - 400 x 10⁹/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
30 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L


Alanine aminotransferase
25 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L


Urine




 Protein
2+
Absent



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gestational hypertension involves new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks’ gestation without significant proteinuria or end-organ dysfunction. This patient has 2+ proteinuria, indicating renal involvement, which is inconsistent with gestational hypertension. Headaches suggest systemic effects beyond isolated hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic hypertension is defined as elevated blood pressure before pregnancy or before 20 weeks’ gestation. This patient is at 34 weeks’ gestation with no prior hypertension history. New-onset headaches and proteinuria suggest a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy rather than a preexisting condition.

C) CORRECT:

Preeclampsia is diagnosed in pregnant patients with new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks’ gestation and significant proteinuria. This patient has a blood pressure of 148/94 mm Hg and 2+ proteinuria, meeting the criteria for preeclampsia. The condition results from abnormal placentation, leading to systemic endothelial dysfunction, hypertension, and proteinuria. Headache and peripheral edema are common clinical features. Normal liver enzymes and platelet counts indicate uncomplicated preeclampsia, distinguishing it from severe variants with multisystem involvement.

Key learning point: Proteinuria is a key diagnostic feature of preeclampsia, indicating kidney involvement in this pregnancy complication.

D) INCORRECT:

HELLP syndrome is characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. This patient has normal liver enzymes and platelet count, with no evidence of hemolysis, excluding HELLP syndrome despite overlapping symptoms like hypertension and headache.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old G1P0 woman at 35 weeks’ gestation presents to the clinic with a severe headache and right upper quadrant pain. She denies visual disturbances or hearing changes. She has no known drug allergies. Physical examination shows hyperreflexia. Laboratory assays reveal normal platelets. She complains that her headache is worsening (see lab result).

Blood pressure
170/112 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 Protein
3+
Absent



Which of the following medications is most appropriate to prevent seizures in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diazepam enhances gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA)-A receptor activity, terminating seizures but not preventing them in severe preeclampsia. Magnesium sulfate is preferred for seizure prophylaxis due to its NMDA receptor antagonism and cerebral membrane stabilization. Diazepam's transplacental transfer poses risks like neonatal sedation.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine is a vasodilator used to manage hypertension in severe preeclampsia, reducing systemic vascular resistance. However, it lacks anticonvulsant properties and does not prevent seizures. Seizure prophylaxis requires agents that directly modulate central nervous system excitability, which hydralazine does not provide.

C) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin stabilizes neuronal membranes by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, reducing excitability in many seizure disorders. However, the pathophysiology of eclamptic seizures involves vascular endothelial dysfunction and cerebral hyperexcitability, which phenytoin does not address. Its side effects, such as arrhythmias, are concerning in this setting.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with severe preeclampsia, characterized by elevated blood pressure, proteinuria, headache, right upper quadrant pain, and hyperreflexia. Intravenous magnesium sulfate is the standard treatment for seizure prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. It stabilizes the neuromuscular junction by reducing neuronal excitability and blocking N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors. Clinical trials support its use, showing a reduction in progression to eclampsia and improved maternal outcomes. Magnesium sulfate also mitigates the severity of any breakthrough seizures. Monitoring serum magnesium levels and neuromuscular function is essential to avoid toxicity.

Key learning point: Magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice for preventing eclampsia in patients with severe preeclampsia.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents to the Outpatient Clinic for a preconception counseling visit. She has long-standing hypertension managed on lisinopril, with no medication side effects. She has no significant medical history apart from hypertension and denies any current symptoms. Examination is normal. Laboratory results are within normal limits. She is eager to conceive within the next few months.

Blood pressure
138/88 mm Hg

What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue lisinopril at the current dose

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Losartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker, shares similar teratogenic risks with lisinopril, including adverse fetal outcomes like renal dysgenesis. Both interfere with the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, making losartan an unsuitable alternative for women planning pregnancy.

B) CORRECT:

Lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, poses teratogenic risks, including impaired fetal renal development and oligohydramnios, due to its interference with the renin-angiotensin system. These risks necessitate discontinuation before conception. Labetalol, a combined alpha- and beta-blocker, is preferred for managing hypertension in women planning pregnancy due to its safety profile.
